Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2018 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Andrew J. Zucker is "Interactions between abstract topological dynamics, Ramsey theory, and descriptive set theory". The host institution for the fellowship is Universite Paris Diderot and the sponsoring scientist is Todor Tsankov.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project undertook original research in the mathematical field of topological dynamics. Historically, this area of research was motivated by physical, "concrete" dynamical systems, i.e. the study of objects in motion. Topological dynamics proceeds by making more abstract both the notion of "object" and that of "motion." An object is represented by a mathematical structure known as a topological space, while the motion of this object is encoded by considering some set of symmetries of this space. By abstracting one step further, one can consider a mathematical structure called a group, which can be thought of as a set of symmetries for many spaces at the same time; the choice of space is then known as a group action.


A major theme of the project was to start with a group and to construct group actions with exotic behavior. One such group we considered was the group of continuous symmetries of the surface of a ball. By "continuous symmetry," we mean that we are allowed to stretch and compress the surface of the ball, but without tearing or pinching it. In joint work with Yonatan Gutman and Todor Tsankov, we constructed a minimal action of this group which is extremely large (where the precise notion of largeness is called being non-metrizable). Other times, rather than starting out with a specific group, we developed constructions of interesting group actions for many groups at the same time. One class of groups frequently considered was the class of countable groups, those groups whose elements can be written down in an infinite list. In joint work with Eli Glasner, Todor Tsankov, and Benjamin Weiss, we constructed for every countable group a large, disjoint family of minimal actions. Here, "disjointness" can be thought of as an extreme form of being pairwise distinct. In a different, solo work, the PI gave a new construction for every countable group of a minimal action which can mimic every possible volume preserving action of said group, simplifying earlier work of Weiss.


Another theme of the project was to explore areas of mathematics which interact with topological dynamics. One such area is called structural Ramsey theory, which seeks to explore how structures behave when partitioned into finitely many pieces. Some well behaved countable structures have the property that for any finite partition, a fixed number of pieces will always contain a copy of the original structure; this is known as having finite big Ramsey degrees. Generalizing recent work of Natasha Dobrinen, the PI showed that a large class of structures have finite big Ramsey degrees. Notable in this work is the technique used; while the result is entirely about countable objects, the proof uses the technique of set-theoretic forcing, and the forcing poset used is extremely large. 


The main broader impact of this project was to develop an international network of collaborators. Several of these collaborators are early career researchers; by building a robust working relationship with them, they might consider bringing their research expertise to the United States as postdoctoral researchers. With the increase in virtual collaboration due to the COVID-19 pandemic, it is likely that many of these collaborations will persist and continue to yield fruitful research.
